an8.45:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
an8.45:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

an8.45:1.2.pli: Atha kho bojjhā upāsikā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho bojjhaṃ upāsikaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an8.45:1.2.eng: Then the laywoman Bojjhā went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to her:

an8.45:2.1.pli: “Aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato, bojjhe, uposatho upavuttho mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro.
an8.45:2.1.eng: “Bojjhā, the observance of the sabbath with its eight factors is very fruitful and beneficial and dazzling and bountiful.

an8.45:2.2.pli: Kathaṃ upavuttho ca, bojjhe, aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato uposatho mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro?
an8.45:2.2.eng: And how should it be observed?

an8.45:2.3.eng: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:

an8.45:2.4.pli: ‘yāvajīvaṃ arahanto pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā nihitadaṇḍā nihitasatthā lajjī dayāpannā sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampino viharanti.
an8.45:2.4.eng: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They are scrupulous and kind, and live full of sympathy for all living beings.

an8.45:2.5.pli: Ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno, sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharāmi.
an8.45:2.5.eng: I, too, for this day and night will give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. I’ll be scrupulous and kind, and live full of sympathy for all living beings.

an8.45:2.6.pli: Imināpaṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi, uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissatī’ti.
an8.45:2.6.eng: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’

an8.45:3.1.pli: ‘Yāvajīvaṃ arahanto uccāsayanamahāsayanaṃ pahāya uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭiviratā nīcaseyyaṃ kappenti—mañcake vā tiṇasanthārake vā.
an8.45:3.1.eng: ‘As long as they live, the perfected ones give up high and luxurious beds. They sleep in a low place, either a cot or a straw mat.

an8.45:3.2.pli: Ahampajja imañca rattiṃ imañca divasaṃ uccāsayanamahāsayanaṃ pahāya uccāsayanamahāsayanā paṭivirato nīcaseyyaṃ kappemi—mañcake vā tiṇasanthārake vā.
an8.45:3.2.eng: I, too, for this day and night will give up high and luxurious beds. I’ll sleep in a low place, either a cot or a straw mat.

an8.45:3.3.pli: Imināpaṅgena arahataṃ anukaromi, uposatho ca me upavuttho bhavissatī’ti.
an8.45:3.3.eng: I will observe the sabbath by doing as the perfected ones do in this respect.’

an8.45:3.5.pli: Evaṃ upavuttho kho, bojjhe, aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato uposatho mahapphalo hoti mahānisaṃso mahājutiko mahāvipphāro.
an8.45:3.5.eng: The observance of the sabbath with its eight factors in this way is very fruitful and beneficial and dazzling and bountiful.

an8.45:4.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bojjhe, yo imesaṃ soḷasannaṃ mahājanapadānaṃ pahūtarattaratanānaṃ issariyādhipaccaṃ rajjaṃ kāreyya, seyyathidaṃ—
an8.45:4.2.eng: Suppose you were to rule as sovereign lord over these sixteen great countries—Aṅga, Magadha, Kāsi, Kosala, Vajji, Malla, Cetī, Vaccha, Kuru, Pañcāla, Maccha, Sūrasena, Assaka, Avanti, Gandhāra, and Kamboja—full of the seven kinds of precious things.

an8.45:4.3.pli: aṅgānaṃ magadhānaṃ kāsīnaṃ kosalānaṃ vajjīnaṃ mallānaṃ cetīnaṃ vaṅgānaṃ kurūnaṃ pañcālānaṃ macchānaṃ sūrasenānaṃ assakānaṃ avantīnaṃ gandhārānaṃ kambojānaṃ, aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgatassa uposathassa etaṃ kalaṃ nāgghati soḷasiṃ.
an8.45:4.3.eng: This wouldn’t be worth a sixteenth part of the sabbath with its eight factors.

an8.45:4.5.pli: Kapaṇaṃ, bojjhe, mānusakaṃ rajjaṃ dibbaṃ sukhaṃ upanidhāya.
an8.45:4.5.eng: Because human kingship is a poor thing compared to the happiness of the gods.

an8.45:5.1.pli: Yāni, bojjhe, mānusakāni paññāsa vassāni, cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ eso eko rattindivo.
an8.45:5.1.eng: Fifty years in the human realm is one day and night for the gods of the four great kings.

an8.45:5.2.eng: Thirty such days make up a month.

an8.45:5.3.eng: Twelve such months make up a year.

an8.45:5.4.pli: Tena saṃvaccharena dibbāni pañca vassasatāni cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ.
an8.45:5.4.eng: The lifespan of the gods of the four great kings is five hundred of these heavenly years.

an8.45:5.5.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bojjhe, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco itthī vā puriso vā aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā cātumahārājikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyya.
an8.45:5.5.eng: It’s possible that some woman or man who has observed the eight-factored sabbath will—when their body breaks up, after death—be reborn in the company of the gods of the four great kings.

an8.45:5.6.pli: Idaṃ kho panetaṃ, bojjhe, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
an8.45:5.6.eng: This is what I was referring to when I said:

an8.45:5.7.eng: ‘Human kingship is a poor thing compared to the happiness of the gods.’

an8.45:6.1.eng: A hundred years in the human realm …

an8.45:6.2.eng: Two hundred years in the human realm …

an8.45:6.3.eng: Four hundred years in the human realm …

an8.45:6.4.eng: Eight hundred years in the human realm …

an8.45:6.5.pli: soḷasa vassasatāni paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ devānaṃ eso eko rattindivo.
an8.45:6.5.eng: Sixteen hundred years in the human realm is one day and night for the gods who control what is created by others.

an8.45:6.6.eng: Thirty such days make up a month.

an8.45:6.7.eng: Twelve such months make up a year.

an8.45:6.8.pli: Tena saṃvaccharena dibbāni soḷasa vassasahassāni paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ devānaṃ āyuppamāṇaṃ.
an8.45:6.8.eng: The life span of the gods who Control what is created by Others is sixteen thousand of these heavenly years.

an8.45:6.9.pli: Ṭhānaṃ kho panetaṃ, bojjhe, vijjati yaṃ idhekacco itthī vā puriso vā aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgataṃ uposathaṃ upavasitvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā paranimmitavasavattīnaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjeyya.
an8.45:6.9.eng: It’s possible that some woman or man who has observed the eight-factored sabbath will—when their body breaks up, after death—be reborn in the company of the gods who control what is created by others.

an8.45:6.10.pli: Idaṃ kho panetaṃ, bojjhe, sandhāya bhāsitaṃ:
an8.45:6.10.eng: This is what I was referring to when I said:

an8.45:6.11.eng: ‘Human kingship is a poor thing compared to the happiness of the gods.’

an8.45:7.1.eng: You shouldn’t kill living creatures, or steal,

an8.45:7.2.pli: Musā na bhāse na ca majjapo siyā;

an8.45:7.4.eng: and don’t eat at night, the wrong time.

an8.45:8.1.pli: Mālaṃ na dhāre na ca gandhamācare,
an8.45:8.1.eng: Not wearing garlands or applying fragrance,

an8.45:8.2.eng: you should sleep on a low bed, <j>or a mat on the ground.

an8.45:8.3.eng: This is the eight-factored sabbath, they say,

an8.45:8.4.eng: explained by the Buddha, <j>who has gone to suffering’s end.

an8.45:9.1.pli: Cando ca suriyo ca ubho sudassanā,
an8.45:9.1.eng: The moon and sun are both fair to see,

an8.45:9.2.eng: radiating as far as they revolve.

an8.45:9.3.eng: Those dispellers of darkness, travellers in midair,

an8.45:9.4.eng: shine in the firmament, lighting up the quarters.

an8.45:10.1.eng: All of the wealth that’s found in this realm—

an8.45:11.1.eng: they’re not worth a sixteenth part

an8.45:11.2.eng: of the mind developed with love,

an8.45:11.3.eng: as starlight cannot rival the moon.

an8.45:12.1.pli: Tasmā hi nārī ca naro ca sīlavā,
an8.45:12.1.eng: So an ethical woman or man,

an8.45:12.2.eng: who has observed the eight-factored sabbath,

an8.45:12.3.eng: having made merit whose outcome is happiness,

an8.45:12.4.eng: blameless, they go to a heavenly place.”

an8.46:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
an8.46:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

an8.46:1.2.pli: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā anuruddho divāvihāraṃ gato hoti paṭisallīno.
an8.46:1.2.eng: Now at that time Venerable Anuruddha had gone into retreat for the day’s meditation.

an8.46:1.3.pli: Atha kho sambahulā manāpakāyikā devatā yenāyasmā anuruddho tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho tā devatā āyasmantaṃ anuruddhaṃ etadavocuṃ:
an8.46:1.3.eng: Then several deities of the Agreeable Host went up to Venerable Anuruddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:

an8.46:1.4.pli: “mayaṃ, bhante anuruddha, manāpakāyikā nāma devatā tīsu ṭhānesu issariyaṃ kārema vasaṃ vattema.
an8.46:1.4.eng: “Honorable Anuruddha, we are the deities called ‘Agreeable’. We wield authority and control over three things.

an8.46:1.5.pli: Mayaṃ, bhante anuruddha, yādisakaṃ vaṇṇaṃ ākaṅkhāma tādisakaṃ vaṇṇaṃ ṭhānaso paṭilabhāma;
an8.46:1.5.eng: We can turn any color we want on the spot.

an8.46:1.6.pli: yādisakaṃ saraṃ ākaṅkhāma tādisakaṃ saraṃ ṭhānaso paṭilabhāma;
an8.46:1.6.eng: We can get any voice that we want on the spot.

an8.46:1.7.pli: yādisakaṃ sukhaṃ ākaṅkhāma tādisakaṃ sukhaṃ ṭhānaso paṭilabhāma.
an8.46:1.7.eng: We can get any pleasure that we want on the spot.

an8.46:1.8.pli: Mayaṃ, bhante anuruddha, manāpakāyikā nāma devatā imesu tīsu ṭhānesu issariyaṃ kārema vasaṃ vattemā”ti.
an8.46:1.8.eng: We are the deities called ‘Agreeable’. We wield authority and control over these three things.”

an8.46:2.2.pli: “aho vatimā devatā sabbāva nīlā assu nīlavaṇṇā nīlavatthā nīlālaṅkārā”ti.
an8.46:2.2.eng: “If only these deities would all turn blue, of blue color, clad in blue, adorned with blue!”

an8.46:2.3.pli: Atha kho tā devatā āyasmato anuruddhassa cittamaññāya sabbāva nīlā ahesuṃ nīlavaṇṇā nīlavatthā nīlālaṅkārā.
an8.46:2.3.eng: Then those deities, knowing Anuruddha’s thought, all turned blue.

an8.46:3.2.eng: “If only these deities would all turn yellow …”

an8.46:3.3.eng: “If only these gods would all turn red …”

an8.46:3.4.pli: sabbāva odātā assu odātavaṇṇā odātavatthā odātālaṅkārā”ti.
an8.46:3.4.eng: “If only these gods would all turn white …”

an8.46:3.5.pli: Atha kho tā devatā āyasmato anuruddhassa cittamaññāya sabbāva odātā ahesuṃ odātavaṇṇā odātavatthā odātālaṅkārā.
an8.46:3.5.eng: Then those deities, knowing Anuruddha’s thought, all turned white.

an8.46:4.1.pli: Atha kho tā devatā ekā ca gāyi ekā ca nacci ekā ca accharaṃ vādesi.
an8.46:4.1.eng: Then one of those deities sang, one danced, and one snapped her fingers.

an8.46:4.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma pañcaṅgikassa tūriyassa suvinītassa suppaṭipatāḷitassa kusalehi susamannāhatassa saddo hoti vaggu ca rajanīyo ca kamanīyo ca pemanīyo ca madanīyo ca;
an8.46:4.2.eng: Suppose there was a quintet made up of skilled musicians who had practiced well and kept excellent rhythm. They’d sound graceful, tantalizing, sensuous, lovely, and intoxicating.

an8.46:4.3.pli: evamevaṃ tāsaṃ devatānaṃ alaṅkārānaṃ saddo hoti vaggu ca rajanīyo ca kamanīyo ca pemanīyo ca madanīyo ca.
an8.46:4.3.eng: In the same way the performance by those deities sounded graceful, tantalizing, sensuous, lovely, and intoxicating.

an8.46:4.4.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho indriyāni okkhipi.
an8.46:4.4.eng: But Venerable Anuruddha averted his senses.

an8.46:5.1.pli: Atha kho tā devatā “na khvayyo anuruddho sādiyatī”ti tatthevantaradhāyiṃsu.
an8.46:5.1.eng: Then those deities, thinking “Master Anuruddha isn’t enjoying this,” vanished right there.

an8.46:5.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā anuruddho bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an8.46:5.2.eng: Then in the late afternoon, Anuruddha came out of retreat and went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened, adding:

an8.46:6.2.pli: Atha kho, bhante, sambahulā manāpakāyikā devatā yenāhaṃ tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā maṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhaṃsu. Ekamantaṃ ṭhitā kho, bhante, tā devatā maṃ etadavocuṃ:

an8.46:6.3.pli: ‘mayaṃ, bhante anuruddha, manāpakāyikā nāma devatā tīsu ṭhānesu issariyaṃ kārema vasaṃ vattema.

an8.46:6.4.pli: Mayaṃ, bhante anuruddha, yādisakaṃ vaṇṇaṃ ākaṅkhāma tādisakaṃ vaṇṇaṃ ṭhānaso paṭilabhāma;

an8.46:6.5.pli: yādisakaṃ saraṃ ākaṅkhāma tādisakaṃ saraṃ ṭhānaso paṭilabhāma;

an8.46:6.6.pli: yādisakaṃ sukhaṃ ākaṅkhāma tādisakaṃ sukhaṃ ṭhānaso paṭilabhāma.

an8.46:6.7.pli: Mayaṃ, bhante anuruddha, manāpakāyikā nāma devatā imesu tīsu ṭhānesu issariyaṃ kārema vasaṃ vattemā’ti.

an8.46:6.9.pli: ‘aho vatimā devatā sabbāva nīlā assu nīlavaṇṇā nīlavatthā nīlālaṅkārā’ti.

an8.46:6.10.pli: Atha kho, bhante, tā devatā mama cittamaññāya sabbāva nīlā ahesuṃ nīlavaṇṇā nīlavatthā nīlālaṅkārā.

an8.46:7.4.pli: sabbāva odātā assu odātavaṇṇā odātavatthā odātālaṅkārā’ti.

an8.46:7.5.pli: Atha kho, bhante, tā devatā mama cittamaññāya sabbāva odātā ahesuṃ odātavaṇṇā odātavatthā odātālaṅkārā.

an8.46:8.1.pli: Atha kho, bhante, tā devatā ekā ca gāyi ekā ca nacci ekā ca accharaṃ vādesi.

an8.46:8.2.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma pañcaṅgikassa tūriyassa suvinītassa suppaṭipatāḷitassa kusalehi susamannāhatassa saddo hoti vaggu ca rajanīyo ca kamanīyo ca pemanīyo ca madanīyo ca;

an8.46:8.3.pli: evamevaṃ tāsaṃ devatānaṃ alaṅkārānaṃ saddo hoti vaggu ca rajanīyo ca kamanīyo ca pemanīyo ca madanīyo ca.

an8.46:9.1.pli: Atha kho, bhante, tā devatā ‘na khvayyo anuruddho sādiyatī’ti tatthevantaradhāyiṃsu.

an8.46:9.2.pli: Katihi nu kho, bhante, dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manāpakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatī”ti?
an8.46:9.2.eng: “How many qualities do ladies have so that—when their body breaks up, after death—they are reborn in company with the Gods of the Agreeable Host?”

an8.46:10.1.pli: “Aṭṭhahi kho, anuruddha, dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manāpakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an8.46:10.1.eng: “Anuruddha, when they have eight qualities ladies—when their body breaks up, after death—are reborn in company with the Gods of the Agreeable Host.

an8.46:10.3.pli: Idha, anuruddha, mātugāmo yassa mātāpitaro bhattuno denti atthakāmā hitesino anukampakā anukampaṃ upādāya tassa hoti pubbuṭṭhāyinī pacchānipātinī kiṅkārapaṭissāvinī manāpacārinī piyavādinī.
an8.46:10.3.eng: Take the case of a lady whose mother and father give her to a husband wanting what’s best for her, out of kindness and sympathy. She would get up before him and go to bed after him, and be obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely.

an8.46:11.1.eng: She honors, respects, esteems, and venerates those her husband respects, such as

an8.46:11.2.pli: mātāti vā pitāti vā samaṇabrāhmaṇāti vā—
an8.46:11.2.eng: mother and father, and ascetics and brahmins.

an8.46:11.3.pli: te sakkaroti, garuṃ karoti, māneti, pūjeti, abbhāgate ca āsanodakena paṭipūjeti.
an8.46:11.3.eng: And when they arrive she serves them with a seat and water.

an8.46:12.1.pli: Ye te bhattu abbhantarā kammantā—uṇṇāti vā kappāsāti vā—tattha dakkhā hoti analasā tatrupāyāya vīmaṃsāya samannāgatā alaṃ kātuṃ alaṃ saṃvidhātuṃ.
an8.46:12.1.eng: She’s deft and tireless in her husband’s household duties, such as knitting and sewing. She understands how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work.

an8.46:13.1.pli: Yo so bhattu abbhantaro antojano—dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā—
an8.46:13.1.eng: She knows what work her husband’s domestic bondservants, servants, and workers have completed, and what they’ve left incomplete.

an8.46:13.2.pli: tesaṃ katañca katato jānāti akatañca akatato jānāti, gilānakānañca balābalaṃ jānāti khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyañcassa paccaṃsena saṃvibhajati.
an8.46:13.2.eng: She knows who is sick, and who is fit or unwell. She distributes to each a fair portion of fresh and cooked foods.

an8.46:14.1.pli: Yaṃ bhattu āharati dhanaṃ vā dhaññaṃ vā jātarūpaṃ vā taṃ ārakkhena guttiyā sampādeti, tattha ca hoti adhuttī athenī asoṇḍī avināsikā.
an8.46:14.1.eng: She ensures that any income her husband earns is guarded and protected, whether money, grain, silver, or gold. She doesn’t overspend, steal, waste, or lose it.

an8.46:15.1.pli: Upāsikā kho pana hoti buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gatā dhammaṃ saraṇaṃ gatā saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ gatā.
an8.46:15.1.eng: She’s a lay follower who has gone for refuge to the Buddha, his teaching, and the Saṅgha.

an8.46:16.2.pli: pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā, adinnādānā paṭiviratā, kāmesumicchācārā paṭiviratā, musāvādā paṭiviratā, surāmerayamajjapamādaṭṭhānā paṭiviratā.
an8.46:16.2.eng: She doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an8.46:17.2.pli: Vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgā payatapāṇinī vossaggaratā yācayogā dānasaṃvibhāgaratā.
an8.46:17.2.eng: She lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

an8.46:18.1.pli: Imehi kho, anuruddha, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manāpakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatīti.
an8.46:18.1.eng: When they possess these eight qualities ladies—when their body breaks up, after death—are reborn in company with the Gods of the Agreeable Host.

an8.46:19.1.eng: She’d never look down on her husband,

an8.46:19.2.eng: who’s always eager to work hard,

an8.46:20.1.eng: And a good woman never scolds her husband

an8.46:21.1.eng: She gets up early, works tirelessly,

an8.46:22.1.eng: A lady who fulfills these duties

an8.47:0.3.eng: With Visākhā on the Agreeable Gods

an8.47:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
an8.47:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.

an8.47:1.2.eng: Then Visākhā, Migāra’s mother, went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.

an8.47:1.3.pli: ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho visākhaṃ migāramātaraṃ bhagavā etadavoca:

an8.47:2.1.pli: “Aṭṭhahi kho, visākhe, dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manāpakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an8.47:2.1.eng: “Visākhā, when they have eight qualities ladies—when their body breaks up, after death—are reborn in company with the Gods of the Agreeable Host.

an8.47:2.3.pli: Idha, visākhe, mātugāmo yassa mātāpitaro bhattuno denti atthakāmā hitesino anukampakā anukampaṃ upādāya tassa hoti pubbuṭṭhāyinī pacchānipātinī kiṅkārapaṭissāvinī manāpacārinī piyavādinī …pe….
an8.47:2.3.eng: Take the case of a lady whose mother and father give her to a husband wanting what’s best for her, out of kindness and sympathy. She would get up before him and go to bed after him, and be obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely. …

an8.47:3.2.pli: Vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgā payatapāṇinī vossaggaratā yācayogā dānasaṃvibhāgaratā.
an8.47:3.2.eng: She lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

an8.47:3.3.pli: Imehi kho, visākhe, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manāpakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatīti.
an8.47:3.3.eng: When they possess these eight qualities ladies—when their body breaks up, after death—are reborn in company with the Gods of the Agreeable Host.

an8.47:4.1.eng: She’d never look down on her husband,

an8.47:4.2.eng: who’s always eager to work hard,

an8.47:5.1.eng: And a good woman never scolds her husband

an8.47:6.1.eng: She gets up early, works tirelessly,

an8.47:7.1.eng: A lady who fulfills these duties

an8.48:0.3.eng: With Nakula’s Mother on the Agreeable Gods

an8.48:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā bhaggesu viharati susumāragire bhesakaḷāvane migadāye.
an8.48:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Bhaggas at Crocodile’s Bellow, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.

an8.48:1.2.pli: Atha kho nakulamātā gahapatānī yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā …pe…. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho nakulamātaraṃ gahapatāniṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an8.48:1.2.eng: Then the housewife Nakula’s mother went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to her:

an8.48:2.1.pli: “Aṭṭhahi kho, nakulamāte, dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manāpakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an8.48:2.1.eng: “Nakula’s mother, when they have eight qualities ladies—when their body breaks up, after death—are reborn in company with the Gods of the Agreeable Host.

an8.48:2.3.pli: Idha, nakulamāte, mātugāmo yassa mātāpitaro bhattuno denti atthakāmā hitesino anukampakā anukampaṃ upādāya tassa hoti pubbuṭṭhāyinī pacchānipātinī kiṅkārapaṭissāvinī manāpacārinī piyavādinī.
an8.48:2.3.eng: Take the case of a lady whose mother and father give her to a husband wanting what’s best for her, out of kindness and sympathy. She would get up before him and go to bed after him, and be obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely.

an8.48:3.1.eng: She honors, respects, esteems, and venerates those her husband respects, such as

an8.48:3.2.pli: mātāti vā pitāti vā samaṇabrāhmaṇāti vā—
an8.48:3.2.eng: mother and father, and ascetics and brahmins.

an8.48:3.3.pli: te sakkaroti garuṃ karoti māneti pūjeti, abbhāgate ca āsanodakena paṭipūjeti.
an8.48:3.3.eng: And when they arrive she serves them with a seat and water.

an8.48:4.1.pli: Ye te bhattu abbhantarā kammantā—uṇṇāti vā kappāsāti vā—tattha dakkhā hoti analasā tatrupāyāya vīmaṃsāya samannāgatā alaṃ kātuṃ alaṃ saṃvidhātuṃ.
an8.48:4.1.eng: She’s deft and tireless in her husband’s household duties, such as knitting and sewing. She understands how to go about things in order to complete and organize the work.

an8.48:5.1.pli: Yo so bhattu abbhantaro antojano—dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā—
an8.48:5.1.eng: She knows what work her husband’s domestic bondservants, servants, and workers have completed, and what they’ve left incomplete.

an8.48:5.2.pli: tesaṃ katañca katato jānāti akatañca akatato jānāti, gilānakānañca balābalaṃ jānāti khādanīyaṃ bhojanīyañcassa paccaṃsena saṃvibhajati.
an8.48:5.2.eng: She knows who is sick, and who is fit or unwell. She distributes to each a fair portion of fresh and cooked foods.

an8.48:6.1.pli: Yaṃ bhattā āharati dhanaṃ vā dhaññaṃ vā rajataṃ vā jātarūpaṃ vā taṃ ārakkhena guttiyā sampādeti, tattha ca hoti adhuttī athenī asoṇḍī avināsikā.
an8.48:6.1.eng: She ensures that any income her husband earns is guarded and protected, whether money, grain, silver, or gold. She doesn’t overspend, steal, waste, or lose it.

an8.48:7.1.pli: Upāsikā kho pana hoti buddhaṃ saraṇaṃ gatā dhammaṃ saraṇaṃ gatā saṅghaṃ saraṇaṃ gatā.
an8.48:7.1.eng: She’s a lay follower who has gone for refuge to the Buddha, his teaching, and the Saṅgha.

an8.48:8.2.eng: She doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.

an8.48:9.1.pli: Cāgavatī kho pana hoti vigatamalamaccherena cetasā agāraṃ ajjhāvasati muttacāgā payatapāṇinī vossaggaratā yācayogā dānasaṃvibhāgaratā.
an8.48:9.1.eng: She’s generous. She lives at home rid of the stain of stinginess, freely generous, open-handed, loving to let go, committed to charity, loving to give and to share.

an8.48:10.1.pli: Imehi kho, nakulamāte, aṭṭhahi dhammehi samannāgato mātugāmo kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā manāpakāyikānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjatīti.
an8.48:10.1.eng: When they possess these eight qualities ladies—when their body breaks up, after death—are reborn in company with the Gods of the Agreeable Host.

an8.48:11.1.eng: She’d never look down on her husband,

an8.48:11.2.eng: who’s always eager to work hard,

an8.48:12.1.eng: And a good woman never scolds her husband

an8.48:13.1.eng: She gets up early, works tirelessly,

an8.48:14.1.eng: A lady who fulfills these duties
